item.title: Dual y-axis in ggplot
item.description: Double vertical axis is a fairly common requirement by the analysts. They often use plots with double y-axis to visualize two different variables where x-axis is common to both of them. While ggplot supports most type of graph, this particular kind is not supported. Hadley believes this type of graphs are fundamentally flawed and even went as far as saying he will never build such a graph in ggplot2 package because:

item.title: Gantt chart using Gvis
item.description: Gantt chart can be very useful to visualize the occurance of certain events on a timeline. If you need create one programmetically, you can use gvis package which utilizes plotting library from Google. # get the data df <- data_get() # make sure you get the data here # convert time to decimal hours, remove if not required df$start.ct <- as.POSIXct(paste(df$`Date Time`, df$start, sep = " ")) df$end.ct <- as.POSIXct(paste(df$`Date Time`, df$end, sep = " ")) df$start.
